description: The bus is the body of the spacecraft and is slightly bigger than a smart car and about as tall as a basketball hoop. Attached to the body are also the solar electric propulsion system, and the deep space optical communication device developed by a team at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory to communicate with a deep space probe using light instead of radio waves to communicate more data in less time.

The X-band radio telecommunications system is an instrument for measuring the gravity field of Psyche. This information will be combined with imagery to better understand the interior structure of Psyche.
The left solar array is a group of solar panels arranged like a cross to provide power to the spacecraft, including the solar electric propulsion system.
The right solar array is a group of solar panels arranged like a cross to provide power to the spacecraft, including the solar electric propulsion system.

The magnetometer is an instrument for detecting and measuring the remnant magnetic field of Psyche. It consists of two magnetic field sensors positioned along a boom and is developed by a team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Technical University Denmark.

The gamma ray and neutron spectrometer is an instrument developed by a team at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory for detecting, measuring, and mapping the elemental composition of Psyche.
